Award.AwardTitle: Sensing more than a quorum: The role of pheromones in the light-organ symbiont Vibrio fischeri
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plants and animals are consistently colonized by bacteria, and these
symbiotic microorganisms often contribute to beneficial processes and/or disease
in their hosts. Many symbiotic bacteria communicate using pheromone signals,
allowing them to coordinate group behaviors during infection. Such pheromone
signaling is typically called ?quorum sensing?, because high cell density is
necessary for pheromones to build up. However, a ?quorum? is typically not
sufficient to induce pheromone-mediated behaviors fully, and bacterial
pheromones are not simply census-taking signals. Importantly, the pheromones
may also function to communicate aspects of the host environment among the
bacteria. This project will use genetic, molecular, microscopic, and microbiological
approaches in exploiting the tractable model symbiosis between the
bacterium Vibrio fischeri and its natural host squid Euprymna scolopes to
examine the relationship between conditions in the host and the symbiont?s use
of pheromones. Pheromone signaling was discovered in V. fischeri and it
remains among the best-understood model systems for such study. The
symbiotic infection occurs in transparent tissue that is only colonized by V.
fischeri, and pheromone signaling during infection results in the emission of
bioluminescence by the bacteria, making the infection relatively simple and the
regulatory output easy to monitor. The scientific aims of this project are to
determine what aspects of the host environment lead to the induction of bacterial
bioluminescence and to determine what role pheromones play in communicating
conditions in the host. A third aim is to integrate research on bacteria-host
symbioses into undergraduate education, both through direct emersion in
research and through the generation of materials to facilitate in-class discussion
of scientific papers. The project will provide insight into the environment
symbiotic bacteria encounter in a host, and how their perception of the host
environment can be integrated with their use of pheromones. The project will
also help train young scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many bacteria use pheromone signals to control group behaviors that are not evident in lone individuals.  Such signaling regulates many processes relevant to humankind, including virulence of plant and animal pathogens, exoenzyme and antibiotic production, beneficial host-microbe interactions, and biofilm production.  Because a group of cells is required for signaling, this process is known as “quorum sensing”; however, a “quorum” can be necessary but not sufficient to induce pheromone-mediated behaviors fully.  Environmental factors also lead to the regulation of pheromone synthesis and responsiveness to the pheromones, suggesting more complicated and interesting roles for bacterial communication in the real world than simply taking a census of local cell density. 

 

Intellectual merit

We used the simple model symbiosis between the bioluminescent bacterium Vibrio fischeri and its natural host squid Euprymna scolopes to examine the relationship between conditions in the host and the symbiont’s use of pheromones to control when it turns on certain genes, particularly those involved in luminescence.  We demonstrated that the accumulation of two major pheromones is controlled and not simply a reflection of how dense the bacterial population is.  We were also able to show that some of the regulatory systems that control pheromone signaling are turned on when the bacteria infect their host.  Importantly, this regulation of gene expression was not uniform among all symbiont cells at all times, but rather indicated spatial and temporal variation in the conditions experienced by bacterial cells in different host microenvironments.  Our results shed light on what the bacteria encounter upon colonizing their symbiotic host, and how they may use pheromones to communicate information about these environmental cues amongst the population.  Our results also support the idea that pheromones are not used simply as census-taking molecules that function as indicators of population density, but rather have the capacity to communicate information about the environment between sub-populations of bacteria.  Because the regulatory circuitry in V. fischeri is similar to certain other bacteria, including pathogens, our results have widespread implications in phenomena like disease and biofouling that are directly important to humankind.

Broader Impacts

Five graduate student researchers and eight undergraduate researchers were supported at least in part and contributed to accomplishing the research aims of the grant.  An additional aim of the proposal was to integrate symbiosis research with undergraduate education.  This included the development of materials to facilitate classroom discussions of primary literature in the field of bacterial symbioses.  These materials were developed collaboratively between the PI and members of his lab, and were introduced into the PI’s undergraduate course in year two.
